Report on attendance at CNO TV Workshop
I would like to mention that Harry Lamb also represented the
MSB at this meeting, but at his own expense. Ho was also a member of
the Hoet Committee for the workshop.
All in all, I felt that this workshop was very worthwhile for
all of the participants. I(m sure they all left Toledo with a keener
awareness of the potentialities of television as a tool for furthering
their educational and informational program, and a better insight and
knowledge of how to plan television programs.
So far as the value of my presence is concerned, I feel that
the comments that I mad© in meetings acquainted the participants with
the work of the HAEB, and I mad© every effort to explain how our organ¬
ization could b© of help in one way or another. I feel that my meeting
with the CNO TV Committee was very valuable, because a lot of these
people were not at all familiar with our organization or what we ax1©
doing. I had many conversations with individuals who were interested
in learning more about the NAJKB. I repeatedly suggested that our
members, in different communities, would be more than glad to help the
representatives of national organizations do a better job through
television, and radio, I might add.
During one of our evening sessions w© heard from representa¬
tives of the JCET (Walter Etay), NCGET (Betty Colclough), ETRG (Hunter
talked for them, since they were unable to sond anyone down), and other
groups. I later pointed out to Malcolm Knowles, Workshop Director,
and Lois McCarthy, Executive Secretary of GKO, that I felt that the
MSB should have been represented on this panel, since w© are really
in a better position to help these people at the Bgraas roots® level
than are any of the other organisations mentioned.. Both of them said
that they realised too late that this was probably true. However, I
think that I had ample opportunity to expound the merits of NAEB in the
maty group discussions, and this I did on what I consider a very sound
basis.
Incidentally, the Willys camera chain was quite interesting.
It will sell for about 17,000-8,000, uses a vldicon, rather than an
iffiago-orthicon tube, usee 16am lenses, and, after some of the bugs have
been worked out, may be vary useful to low budget educational stations
just getting started. This workshop was used as a sort of ^shakedown
cruise® for the equipment. I could probably supply more detailed
information, not too technical, if you want it. (The technical data on
the Willys TV package was distributed with the August 1953 Newsletter.)
I have attached a list of those attending the workshop for
your information.
This is a rather brief report of say activities and of the GKO
Workshop, but I have more detailed information in say files which can bs
